content: The President must submit a report to Congress evaluating other countries' failure to comply with UN resolutions on North Korea, including closing representative offices, expelling North Korean nationals, and prohibiting new branches of North Korean financial institutions. The report can be unclassified with a classified annex. The President must provide briefings on measures to deny specialized financial messaging services to designated North Korean financial institutions to appropriate congressional committees every 180 days for 5 years. The President must provide briefings every 180 days for 5 years to congressional committees on persons or foreign governments providing financial messaging services to North Korean financial institutions. The briefing should also include an assessment of Treasury's efforts to collaborate with relevant authorities in the home jurisdictions of these service providers. The briefing required under subsection (a) may be classified. Subtitle B--Sanctions With Respect to Human Rights Abuses by the Government of North Korea SEC. 321 of the North Korea Sanctions and Policy Enhancement Act of 2016 introduces sanctions for trafficking in persons, specifically targeting foreign persons who knowingly employ North Korean laborers. This includes the requirement for additional determinations and reports for countries identified under this act. Section 302(a) of the Act requires determinations on individuals from identified countries meeting criteria for sanctions under trafficking prevention laws. These determinations must be included in the annual trafficking in persons report and considered in government decisions. The Act requires determinations on individuals from identified countries for sanctions under trafficking prevention laws. Goods made with North Korean labor are presumed prohibited under certain conditions. The Tariff Act of 1930 prohibits entry of goods produced with convict, forced, or indentured labor. Sanctions can be imposed on foreign persons employing North Korean labor, as designated by the President. The Tariff Act of 1930 prohibits goods produced with forced labor. Sanctions under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act can block transactions involving property of designated persons. The President can't designate a person under subsection (a) if assurances are received regarding North Korean laborers. The Tariff Act of 1930 prohibits goods produced with forced labor, and sanctions can be imposed under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act. The President cannot designate a person under subsection (a) if assurances are received regarding North Korean laborers, ensuring that their wages are not transferred to the Government of North Korea and that they work under international standards. Recertification is required every 180 days to confirm these conditions are met. The Tariff Act of 1930 prohibits goods produced with forced labor, and sanctions can be imposed under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act. Recertification every 180 days is required to confirm that North Korean laborers are not transferring wages to the Government of North Korea and are working under international standards. If recertification cannot be transmitted, sanctions will be imposed. SEC. 322 of the North Korea Sanctions and Policy Enhancement Act of 2016 includes modifications to sanctions suspension and waiver authorities, such as exemptions and humanitarian waivers for goods made with North Korean labor. SEC. 323 of the North Korea Sanctions and Policy Enhancement Act of 2016 introduces amendments to the State Department Basic Authorities Act of 1956 regarding rewards for informants who identify individuals aiding foreign governments in violating US laws or disrupting financial mechanisms. SEC. 324 of the North Korea Sanctions and Policy Enhancement Act of 2016 requires the Secretary of State to determine within 90 days if North Korea should be designated as a state sponsor of terrorism. The determination must be submitted to congressional committees in unclassified form, with the option of a classified annex. The term "state sponsor of terrorism" refers to a country whose government has repeatedly supported acts of international terrorism, as defined by various provisions of law. Subtitle C--General Authorities SEC. 331 allows for the consolidation of reports required under this title or any amendments, with similar deadlines, into a single report to be submitted to congressional committees. The consolidated report must include all necessary information and elements mandated by previous law. SEC. 332 clarifies that nothing in this title limits the President's authority to apply sanctions as described in the North Korea Sanctions and Policy Enhancement Act of 2016. SEC. 333 of this Act mandates the President to promulgate regulations within 180 days for the implementation of this title and its amendments. Before issuing a regulation, the President must notify the appropriate congressional committees at least 10 days in advance. SEC. 334 imposes a limitation on funds. SEC. 334 imposes a limitation on funds for carrying out the requirements of this title and its amendments. No additional funds are authorized, and existing amounts will be used instead.
